metadata.title: COVID-19: person-level drill down | by Raman Samusevich | Towards Data Science
metadata.description: There are mainly cumulative COVID-19 statistics for larger populations, e.g. country-level counts of infected people. Being valuable, it tells us little about COVID-19 situation for an age/gender…

all_paragraphs: There are mainly cumulative COVID-19 statistics for larger populations, e.g. country-level counts of infected people.
Being valuable, it tells us little about COVID-19 situation for an age/gender group our parents belong to, or the group of our partners, or our siblings’ age/gender.
Let’s do a comprehensive drill-down into person-level information about age and gender groups.

We’ll investigate data about COVID-19 patients in The Czech Republic, the data are available at the Ministry of Health of the Czech Republic webpage. To put the COVID-19 situation into demographics context, we’ll use data from the Czech Statistical Office website.

Note, that the data about positive COVID-19 cases are likely to be biased towards people who not only contracted COVID-19, but at the same time had moderate, severe, or critical symptoms. Let’s still say “contracting COVID-19/be exposed to COVID-19” instead of more precise but verbose “contracting COVID-19 and having moderate, severe, or critical symptoms”.

We know that COVID-19 didn’t originate in The Czech Republic. Let’s investigate what we know about imported COVID-19 cases, starting with broad overviews and then diving into finer details as we go along.
What are the overall counts of imported COVID-19 cases per each country of exposure?
We’ve seen where the imported cases originated from. Let’s now overview when it was happening.
The good news is that the absolute count of imported COVID-19 cases seems to have a decreasing trend lately.
Let’s first check cumulative counts per different countries.
For this purpose, I’ve created an interactive visualization, which can be accessed via this link. Please, feel free to explore various details by playing with the visualization yourself.
As an appetizer, for each interactive visualization that is hosted separately, I’m going to post short GIFs with brief comments.

On the GIF above we can see how COVID-19 import into Czechia started from Italy. Later, Czech people were exposed to COVID-19 all over the globe. Yet, Italy and Austria, which lies between Italy and Czechia, remained the dominant countries of exposure. Interestingly, not a single Czech patient was exposed to the virus in China.
We’ve seen the evolution of a total cumulative count per country. Let’s now check weekly counts of imported COVID-19 cases per country of exposure. For the GIF I’ll focus on Europe.
Again, please, feel free to play with this interactive visualization via this link.

After zooming into Europe, we can see that during the early weeks of epidemic almost all imported COVID-19 cases originated in Italy. Later, while Italy still kept being a dominant source of exposure, Austria became the 2nd most active source of exposure to the virus. Later, the majority of weekly imports originated in Austria. And finally, the counts of imports went down. It leaves an impression almost as if we observed a wave of imports to Czechia which originated from Italy with Austria being the main transshipment point between Italy and Czechia.

While investigating COVID-19 cases imported into The Czech Republic, we’ve simultaneously checked the questions “Where from, When, and How many?”. However, we haven’t analyzed the gender of the patients. Let’s now focus on it.
Let’s find out weekly counts of female and male Czech patients imported COVID-19.
Firstly, with weekly aggregations we can better see the decrease of imported cases total count for both men and women. Let’s hope it stays this way.
Secondly, we can see that there are systematically more men than women among imported COVID-19 cases. Does it hold for all age groups? Let’s drill-down into age/gender groups.
Let’s first see overall counts of imported cases per age for each gender.

It’s interesting to see that men and women in their 20’s have similar importing activity, women are more active actually. Then, for both genders, the “importing activity” goes down with age until 40, and it decreases especially quickly for women. It might be due to children, as based on official statistics, in Czechia the average age of first-time mothers is 29 years (source in Czech). Carrying on to higher age groups, we can see local distribution modes corresponding to the mid-forties for both genders. Women in their mid 40’s imported more COVID-19 cases compared to women in their mid 30’s. Yet, men in their 40’s are the most active importing group overall.
Did the most active age/gender groups are the same for countries of exposure? Let’s find out.

Let’s create separate interactive visualizations, one for Females and one for Males. Both visualizations would share the same color scale so that we can visually compare selected age/gender groups. One can check the precise count of cases from any country/age/gender by moving a mouse to the corresponding bin of the visualization.
Original size visualizations can be found here (women) and here (men).
We can see that typical patient age differs from country to country.
For instance, in the United Kingdom young people in their 20’s were the largest age group among imported cases for both genders.
Among Czech patients exposed to COVID-19 in Italy, people in their 40’s, 50’s, and 60’s were the most numerous groups, with more men in their 60’s compared to women count for the same gender.
On the other hand, cases imported from Austria correspond to younger age groups compared to Italian cases.
These differences might suggest prevailing reasons for visiting one country or another (e.g. studies vs. jobs vs. family recreation).

For Austria we can see differences in age distributions between Females and Males. Ladies in their 20’s are the most numerous age group among Females caught COVID-19 there. Moreover, for Austria there were more women in this age category than men. Regarding men exposed to the virus in Austria, gentlemen in their 30’s and 40’s were the most active group of COVID-19 importers to Czechia. The most active among all age/gender groups from all countries.
In the analyses above we did not investigate the time of imports. Does importing activity of a particular age/gender group change over time?
It’s great to see that importing activity has been decreasing lately overall age/gender groups.
Among other observations, one can note the increase of imported cases over March for men in their 60’s. While for men in their 20’s or younger the general trend is the other way around.

We’ve first seen age/gender counts of imported COVID-19 cases per different countries, then we’ve checked imports per age/gender in time. Let’s now try to combine these two views and check gender proportions among the imported cases per country in time.
Let’s investigate the weekly proportion of Females among new patients using an interactive visualization I’ve hosted here.

We’re analyzing weekly aggregations. Yet, sometimes we have just one or two imported cases from a particular country. Then, the color tells us about a single person. It might be more interesting to check possible tendencies for the dominant “importers” with significant weekly counts of cases: Italy and Austria.

It seems that Italy’s been consistently exporting more or less the same proportion of both genders (except perhaps the 2nd week of March and the 1st week of April, when there were slightly more men). I’ve got curious, which Czech regions the patients exposed to the virus in Italy were from.

There were significantly more male patients contracted COVID-19 in Austria, except for the middle of March and the last week with just 8 cases total. Might those be mainly business trips? And let’s also quickly check which Czech regions the Austria cases were imported to.
Lastly, we’re going to also check the average age of imports per country in time.
An interactive visualization enabling to investigate the age info in detail can be found here.
As an example of possible things one might be curious about, I’d like to see when the younger people have brought COVID-19 from the UK.

It’s interesting to see the average age of importers from the UK to decrease in the second part of March and the beginning of April. After a brief googling, on this webpage I came across “essential advice” for students to stay at home, it was dated March 24th. Could this be a possible explanation for what we’ve seen, suggesting returning students?
To answer this, let’s check the daily proportion of imported cases vs. local cases.
It’s important to analyze what’s going on in The Czech Republic in general.
Let’s first check high-level summaries. What are the overall age distributions per each gender of the COVID-19 positive patients?
We can observe two interesting differences between the distributions of Females vs. Males.

It seems that Females in their 30’s contract COVID-19 less frequently compared to Males in the same age group. The same holds for Females vs. Males in their 70’s. Moreover, Women in there 30’s have less corona cases than women in their 20’s. We’ve mentioned already that n Czechia the average age of first-time mothers is 29 years, and the average age of all mothers giving birth is 31(source in Czech). Can having children lead to more efficient self-isolation and social distancing, resulting in the observed proportion of Females in their 30's? We’ll check proportions of the age/gender groups in the general population later and will conclude then.
We’ve checked the gender of patients. And what about the overall distribution of COVID-19 patients per region?

Oh, Prague… It should be noted that based on official stats, the overall population of the Central Bohemian Region is slightly higher than the population of Prague. Yet, the population density in Prague is more than 30x higher, which might mean significantly harder to social-distance.
We’ve seen “Who” (age distributions) and “Where” (regions distribution) separately. Let’s now drill down into combined details.
Let’s see age distributions of COVID-19 patients of each gender per every region using interactive visualization.
We’ve previously seen that Women in their 30’s have less COVID-19 cases compared to women in their 20’s. Now we can see that the same also holds for Men in several regions!

One can also notice different shifts of age distributions in different regions. For instance, the Olomouc Female distribution is shifted towards younger Women, while Ústí nad Labem seems to have a slight shift towards older Ladies. However, according to the official population statistics, the average Female age in Olomouc region is slightly higher than the average age of Women in Ústí nad Labem. Olomouc is known to be a “student” city with up to 1/5 of all people there being students from all over the country (reference in Czech). This observation will help us during the analysis of higher-risk groups.
So, we’ve been looking at “Who” and “Where”, completely ignoring the timeline of the epidemic. Let’s add the question of “When?” into our drill-down!
The interactive visualization can be found here.

Final cumulative counts dominate earlier statistics, making it difficult to visually check what was happening in the beginning. The logarithmic color scale would enable us to better see earlier stages of the epidemic, for more details about log-scale one can check the corresponding wiki page.
We can see how the epidemic started in Ústí and Prague, then central and eastern regions became leaders in COVID-19 counts, and they keep being “leaders” till the time of writing this blog.
We’ve investigated total counts of positive cases per each region in time. Let’s now check COVID-19 patients per age/gender groups in time.

The detailed visualization enables us to check, for instance, groups of older people. We can see that in the beginning of epidemic men in their 60’s had one of the highest daily counts of new COVID-19 cases among all male age groups at that time. We know that the Czech government implemented additional measures of protecting older people rather early on. And in the data we can see that for people in 60’s the daily increase of new patients does not grow as it does for younger age groups. For a week or so the daily count of new cases count went down for people in their 60’s. However, later the counts started to pop, especially for men in this age category the counts got closer to other age groups on the same date. Another troubling observation is high counts of the new cases for Females in their 40’s.
Let’s now investigate gender proportions among new patients per region in time.
To reduce noise, we compute and visualize weekly statistics.
Please, feel free to play with the interactive visualization yourself, checking out various details. The visualization sits here.

The visualization enables us to see that usually counts of new Female and new Male patients differ, even for larger samples during later weeks, when there’re many new COVID-19 patients. Let’s note the week started on March 30. In all regions there’re more Females among new COVID-19-positive patients.
What about the average age of new patients during that week? Let’s check.
Again, you can find the interactive visualization on this address and check any details.
Here I’m going to focus on the week started on March 30, when we’ve noticed a systematically higher proportion of new Female patients.

It seems that during this week people in their late 40’s contracted COVID-19 the most. It might suggest that in Czechia Females in their 40’s might be an age/gender group with a higher risk of contracting COVID-19.
Let’s analyze the risk of contracting COVID-19 per age/gender groups more formally.
First of all, let us check that data suggest different risks per age/gender groups comparing to what we’d expect based on demographics.

Let’s formulate a null hypothesis that COVID-19 attacks any person at random, no matter what age/gender group. Next, let’s check if data provide enough evidence against this hypothesis. If so, we’ll reject the hypothesis. That’s how statisticians often verify facts using data. And here goes a related joke.
Details on how we’re going to check this

In this section I’d provide a brief stats intro. Readers with a strong statistical background might wanna skip this section. On the other hand, I’d be grateful for possible corrections in my description.

We’ll use data about Czechia demographics to compute proportions of each age/gender group. Using these proportions we’ll compute expected frequencies of COVID-19-positive patients in each age/gender category. We would expect these frequencies if the null hypothesis was true, i.e., if every age/gender group was contracting COVID-19 evenly.

Then we would summarize the discrepancy between these expected frequencies and the observed frequencies using one number, so-called statistic chi-square denoted χ2. The mathematicians know how likely different values of χ2 are if the null hypothesis is true. This would enable us to check how unlikely our data are if different age/gender groups contract COVID-19 evenly. Based on it we’ll decide whether we should reject the null hypothesis.

It’s a good practice to agree beforehand, under which conditions we’re going to reject the null hypothesis, otherwise, one might be tempted to project one’s own beliefs into the interpretations of the results. As Ronald H. Coase once said,
If you torture the data long enough, it will confess to anything.
We’ll see another joke about the test results interpretation shortly, but for everyone to fully understand it we need to refresh a definition of p-value.

We’ve discussed that statistic χ2 summarizes the discrepancy between what we observe and what we expect. The higher the χ2 value, the higher the discrepancy. In other words, the higher the χ2 value, the less likely our data are with the null hypothesis being true. P-value is the probability of getting our χ2 value or χ2 values even higher (i.e. values testifying against the hypothesis even more) while the null hypothesis is true.

To sum up, the lower the p-value we get, the less probable our observations under true null hypothesis assumption are, and therefore the safer it is to reject the null hypothesis, which is denoted H₀.

As mentioned already, it’s good to agree before conducting a statistical experiment, what it means for the p-value to be “low”. It’s common to set a threshold we’ll compare the obtained p-value with. If the p-value would be less than the threshold, then the null hypothesis will be rejected. This threshold is called the significance level and is denoted α. Let’s agree to test whether COVID-19 attacks all age/gender groups evenly with a significance level of α=5%.
And here goes the promised joke about the interpretation of the results.
If interested in refreshing technical details of the statistical test we’re going to perform, one might wanna watch a short video from Khan Academy.
We’ve checked preconditions for the Pearson’s chi-square test and then obtained p-value = 1.8*10⁻¹⁶². Therefore, we safely reject the null hypothesis with a significance level of α=5%.
Let visually compare the observed COVID-19 age/gender proportions with the population proportions.
No surprise we’ve rejected the null hypothesis given such huge difference in proportions for people under 20.
Let’s now check each age/gender category separately. As we’re going to perform multiple tests using the same data sample, let’s apply Holm correction.
What’s wrong with multiple tests on the same data?
Again, readers with a strong statistical background might wanna skip this section.
Performing multiple tests using the same data leads to a so-called multiple-comparisons or a multiple-analysis problem. The problem is similar to rolling a dice multiple times.

We know that the probability of getting 6 is 1/6 or approximately 17%. Let’s imagine that you rolled a dice and got 5. You’re unhappy with the result of your “analysis”, so you re-roll the dice. Let’s say you’re unhappy again, so you re-roll once more and this time you get the desired 6. However, the probability of getting 6 at least once when rolling three dice is 42%, not 17% anymore.

Something similar happens if you test multiple subgroups of your data sample. The more subgroups there are, the more likely one of the subgroups is going to “confess” by chance, as in the Coase’s quote
If you torture the data long enough, it will confess to anything.

So, when repeating the same hypothesis test for multiple groups there’s a higher risk of getting low p-value for some group by chance. In this case we would falsely reject a true null hypothesis. This type of error is called a Type I error.
It can be shown that for a single hypothesis test with a significance level α probability of Type I error is less or equal to α.

If we’d like to keep the probability of Type I error under α in the case of multiple tests, we’ll need to correct p-values before comparing it with α. The most basic correction is the so-called Bonferroni correction when for m tests each p-value is multiplied by m before comparing with α. Bonferroni correction is however very conservative and is known to often fail to reject false null hypothesis. In our case it’d mean that risk of contracting COVID-19 is different for different age/gender groups, yet we fail to reject the null hypothesis about the risk being the same.
This type of error is called a Type II error.

We’ll use Holm correction which is an improvement of Bonferroni correction, technical details can be found, e.g., in the wiki. It should be noted that the test is still rather conservative and still might lead to Type II errors.
A note about per-group chi-square test

Experienced readers have already noticed that by performing the chi-square test group by group we’ll have a chi-square distribution with one degree of freedom, which is just a squared normal distribution. Therefore, effectively we’ll be doing something similar to z-test for difference in proportions, and therefore we must check corresponding preconditions, which we’ve done. There were less than 10 expected male patients older than 90, so we excluded the age group 90–110 from the analysis.
Separate results for each age/gender group

As a result of repeated tests with Holm correction, for the majority of age/gender groups the null hypothesis was rejected in favor of the alternative that the age/gender group isn’t exposed to COVID-19 at random.

Let’s compute the difference between COVID-19 age/gender group proportion and proportion expected based on demographics. For groups without statistical difference from random exposure to COVID-19 let’s insert zero. Let’s depict an increased exposure to COVID-19 with red and the decreased exposure with green.

We’ve simply used the direct difference between COVID-19 and general population proportions. Let’s compute more conservative estimates of quantitative differences in the proportions using confidence intervals.
Let me illustrate what I’m going to do it on one concrete example. My mother belongs to Women between 50–59, I’ll use this group for running example.
The results are summaries as before:
And for the age/gender groups with increased risk, let’s visualize the risk increase together with group proportion.
Overall, I’d view this exploratory data analysis as relatively preliminary and would suggest to repeat and extend it once better person-level data are available.
If interested, please feel free to carry on with analyzing this data either by forking a corresponding Kaggle kernel or GitHub repo.
Take care and stay healthy, everyone!
